conclusion: A uniform horizontal wire ab of length L is suspended vertically below two identical spring scales.
A uniform magnetic field B is directed perpendicular to the plane of the paper and into the paper.
A current I flows through the wire from a to b, creating a magnetic force on the wire due to the interaction with the magnetic field.
The magnetic force acts vertically upward or downward depending on the direction of the current.
The magnetic force F_mag on a current-carrying wire in a magnetic field is given by F_mag = I L B.
The spring scales measure the tension in the wire, which is affected by the gravitational force acting on the wire and the magnetic force.
Let the total weight of the wire be evenly distributed between the two spring scales, so without any magnetic force, each spring scale would read F_gravity per scale = mg/2.
When a current I flows from a to b, the magnetic force F_mag = I L B acts upward, reducing the tension in the spring scales.
The reading of each spring scale becomes F_1 = mg/2 - I L B/2.
When the current is reversed and its magnitude becomes 2I, the magnetic force F_mag = 2I L B acts downward, increasing the tension in the spring scales.
The reading of each spring scale becomes F_2 = mg/2 + 2I L B/2.
Subtract the first equation from the second: F_2 - F_1 = (mg/2 + 2I L B/2) - (mg/2 - I L B/2).
Simplify: F_2 - F_1 = 2I L B/2 + I L B/2 = 3I L B/2.
Solve for B: B = 2(F_2 - F_1)/(3I L).
The magnetic induction intensity B of the uniform magnetic field is B = 2(F_2 - F_1)/(3I L).
